summary.para: Adds a node to the topology.

returns.para: The method returns an HRESULT. Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following table.

item.description: pNode is invalid, possibly because the node already exists in the topology.

summary.para: Removes all nodes from the topology.

returns.para: The method returns an HRESULT. Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following table.

remarks.para: You do not need to clear a topology before disposing of it. The Clear method is called automatically when the topology is destroyed.

summary.para: Converts this topology into a copy of another topology.

param.name: pTopology
param.para: A pointer to the interface of the topology to clone.

returns.para: If this method succeeds, it returns S_OK. Otherwise, it returns an HRESULT error code.

item.description: Removes all of the nodes from this topology.
Clones the nodes from pTopology and adds them to this topology. The cloned nodes have the same node identifiers as the nodes from pTopology.
Connects the cloned nodes to match the connections in pTopology.
Copies the attributes from pTopology to this topology.
Copies the topology identifier from pTopology to this topology.

summary.para: Gets a node in the topology, specified by index.

param.name: wIndex
param.para: The zero-based index of the node. To get the number of nodes in the topology, call .

param.name: ppNode
param.para: Receives a pointer to the node's interface. The caller must release the pointer.

returns.para: The method returns an HRESULT. Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following table.

description.para: The index is less than zero.
No node can be found at the index wIndex.

summary.para: Gets a node in the topology, specified by node identifier.

param.name: qwTopoNodeID
param.para: The identifier of the node to retrieve. To get a node's identifier, call .

param.name: ppNode
param.para: Receives a pointer to the node's interface. The caller must release the interface.

returns.para: The method returns an HRESULT. Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following table.

description.para: The topology does not contain a node with this identifier.

summary.para: Gets the number of nodes in the topology.

returns.para: If this method succeeds, it returns S_OK. Otherwise, it returns an HRESULT error code.

summary.para: Gets the output nodes in the topology.

param.name: ppCollection
param.para: Receives a pointer to the interface. The caller must release the pointer. The collection contains IUnknown pointers to all of the output nodes in the topology. Each pointer can be queried for the interface. The collection might be empty.

returns.para: If this method succeeds, it returns S_OK. Otherwise, it returns an HRESULT error code.

summary.para: Gets the source nodes in the topology.

param.name: ppCollection
param.para: Receives a pointer to the interface. The caller must release the pointer. The collection contains IUnknown pointers to all of the source nodes in the topology. Each pointer can be queried for the interface. The collection might be empty.

returns.para: If this method succeeds, it returns S_OK. Otherwise, it returns an HRESULT error code.

summary.para: Gets the identifier of the topology.

param.name: pID
param.para: Receives the identifier, as a TOPOID value.

returns.para: If this method succeeds, it returns S_OK. Otherwise, it returns an HRESULT error code.

summary.para: Removes a node from the topology.

returns.para: The method returns an HRESULT. Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following table.

description.para: The specified node is not a member of this topology.

remarks.para: This method does not destroy the node, so the pointer is still valid after the method returns.
The method breaks any connections between the specified node and other nodes.

summary.para: Represents a topology. A topology describes a collection of media sources, sinks, and transforms that are connected in a certain order. These objects are represented within the topology by topology nodes, which expose the interface. A topology describes the path of multimedia data through these nodes.
